webTitle: Soaring house prices spread across UK as surveyors warn of another bubble

fields.bodyText: House prices are rising at their fastest pace for almost seven years, according to the latest survey to point to a property market on the rise. Rising prices and growing demand have also driven a jump in the number of people putting their homes on the market, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics). Its survey echoed a report from Britain's largest mortgage lender, Halifax, last week that house prices were 5.4% higher than in the summer of 2012. Estate agents polled by Rics indicated the fastest rise in prices since their peak in late 2006 as government schemes such as Funding for Lending continued to improve access to mortgages. Rics warned, however, of the risk of prices soaring to unaffordable levels, echoing commentators who have warned that George Osborne's property market schemes could spark another house price bubble. The group said that although the market conditions were prompting more people to put their home on the market, demand still outstripped supply. "During August, the number of would-be buyers increased yet again as increasingly accessible finance allowed more people to enter the market," the Rics report said. Peter Bolton King, the Rics global residential director, added: "It's not surprising that more and more people are looking to sell their homes. Buyers are out there and prices are on the up so if you're looking to move it's a good time to do so. What we don't wish to see, however, is prices rise to such an extent that they become unaffordable. "For the market to work properly, it's vital that property is both accessible and affordable, and we'll be monitoring the situation very carefully as the housing sector continues to recover." Following government moves to improve access to mortgages, there have been reports of first-time buyers flocking into the housing market. LSL Property Services, which owns estate agencies including Your Move, suggested last week that there were more than 26,000 first-time buyer transactions in July – an increase of 45% on the same month in 2012. The Rics report said the Funding for Lending scheme and Help to Buy "appear to be part of the reason for the pick-up in activity". The report's headline prices balance stood at 40, based on the proportion of respondents reporting a rise in prices minus those reporting a fall. That was the highest since November 2006 and compared with 36 a month earlier. Rics said each region across the country saw supply increase in August as the recovery continued to spread from south-east England to other areas. The South West and the North East, in particular, saw the number of new homes coming onto the market rise significantly. Rics added: "It seems that recent price rises are going to continue unabated." The estate agents surveyed expect prices across Britain, on average, to increase by 2.2% over the coming year and by 4.4% in each of the next five years. At the start of this year, those respective figures were 0.6% and 3.4%. The survey of 348 agents will intensify fears of unsustainable rises that will leave another generation saddled with huge debts. Experts' concerns about another bubble centre on the Help to Buy scheme, which was introduced in April and provides equity loans for first-time buyers of up to 20% towards the cost of new-build properties worth up to £600,000. The International Monetary Fund and others have criticised the scheme, which will be expanded in January to make the loans available to all buyers and all types of property up to the £600,000 limit. Some of the estate agents surveyed by Rics predicted a boom as a result of the government schemes; others were more cautious about their impact. "The second stage of the government's Help to Buy scheme in January 2014 could create a bubble," said Michael Brooker, an agent in Crowborough, East Sussex. Others were less confident the price rises would last. Julian Dyer in the Welsh town of Abergavenny, said: "The market has definitely perked up over the last 6 months, however the market seems very fragile, and I am not convinced that the upturn is sustainable. The government initiative to help builders does not seem to have worked in this area."

webTitle: Shopping centres and out-of-town retail parks hit harder than high streets

fields.standfirst: Shopping centres have highest proportion of empty shops, while out-of-town retail parks are declining the fastest
fields.body:
Shopping centres and out-of-town retail parks are the surprise victims of the economic downturn, according to new figures published on Tuesday.

Campaigners may be concentrating on the plight of small towns, but shopping centres have the highest proportion of empty shops, at 16%, compared with 9.2% in small towns and a national average across all types of retail centre of 14%.

While out-of-town retail parks have a relatively low level of shop vacancies at 9.6%, these centres saw the fastest rate of decline in the first half of this year compared to the first six months of 2012 according to the latest figures from retail research firm the Local Data Company.

Matthew Hopkinson, the LDC's director, said the collapse of electricals chain Comet was likely to have contributed to an 18% rise in the proportion of vacancies at out-of-town parks. Shopping centre vacancies remain steady while vacancies in all other types of centre have reduced.

Maureen Hinton, an analyst at market research company Verdict, said retail parks are suffering as shoppers' habits change. "People don't want to drive regularly to out-of-town stores because it's expensive while they can search for big expensive items online and get them delivered." She added that supermarkets' move way from expansion out of town and back towards convenience stores on the high street was now being reflected in other parts of the market.

Meanwhile the figures highlight a growing north-south divide. The north west of England suffers from the highest level of shop vacancies at 20% compared to just 9.4% in London, the best performing region.

webTitle: UK GDP growth limited to 1% in longer term, economists warn

fields.standfirst: IEA paper predicts a post-crisis era of sluggish growth, tempering recent good economic news stories
fields.body:
Britain's economic growth will be limited to just 1% in the longer term as higher government spending, dwindling North Sea oil stocks and an ageing population all take their toll on the country's potential output, a group of economists has warned.

Tempering the recent spate of upbeat news on the UK and chancellor George Osborne's assertion that the economy has "turned a corner", a new paper predicts a post-crisis era of sluggish growth.

The long-term, sustainable growth rate in the UK may be only 1%, compared with the 2.5% that the Treasury thought standard from the 1980s to the 2000s, according to a discussion paper for free-market thinktank the Institute of Economic Affairs (IEA). "Until 2008 the UK had got used to our economy doubling in size every 25 years: unless action is taken it will now only double in size every 70 years," says the group of economists, which includes former Treasury adviser and UK Independence Party candidate Tim Congdon, and Andrew Lilico, the managing director of Europe Economics, an economics consultancy.

They highlight the weakest recovery in "industrial history" and blame a lack of growth for the government's deficit reduction plan being off target.

Commenting on the analysis, the IEA's editorial director, Philip Booth, said: "People shouldn't get too excited about better growth figures and recent forecasts from groups such as the OECD [Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]. We still have a long way to go before we recover the loss of output from the 2008 crash. Furthermore, the medium-term prospects for growth do not look healthy unless the government determinedly reduces government spending and regulation."

Following a string of positive indicators on the fledgling UK recovery, the OECD has lifted its forecast for the country's economic growth in 2013. The upgrade to projected growth of 1.5% this year came after stronger-than-expected growth of 0.7% in the second quarter, falling unemployment, and survey evidence suggesting the strongest growth in manufacturing output for almost two decades.

But the economists writing in the IEA paper painted a gloomier current economic picture, noting that five years on from the start of the financial crisis in 2008, GDP is still 3% below its peak. "That is unprecedented in 170 years of shocks that have hit the UK economy since industrialisation," sais the paper, "Will flat-lining become normal?"

Predicting sluggish growth rates, the IEA authors blame higher government spending and tax as a proportion of GDP, more regulation of energy and financial services, the depletion of North Sea oil, higher debt levels for government, business and households relative to GDP. They also note demographic pressures from an ageing population as well as the effects of "low-productivity immigrant workers being added to the working population", though the IEA stressed this was an analysis of the impact of much of the UK's immigrant labour being relatively unskilled, not an argument against immigration.

The paper advocates "bold" reforms if the UK wants to get back to sustainable growth rates of around 2% or more over the long run, including: the rolling back of government activity and influence; the regeneration of affordable credit channels to unencumbered households and businesses; and the implementation of radical supply-side measures.

Booth added: "Britain's growth problem is a productivity problem and not a problem caused by insufficient government borrowing. The government should take note. The solutions lie in its hands."

The comments from the free-market thinktank contrast with remarks from the leader of the UK's trade union movement, Frances O'Grady, on Monday. In her first speech to the annual congress as TUC general secretary, O'Grady called for the implementation of a political action plan to stimulate growth, paid for by taxing the rich, whose wealth had increased dramatically in the past few years.

webTitle: Letters: Living standards the test of recovery

fields.body:
"Osborne will say that the best way of safeguarding living standards is growth" (Miliband vows to get tough on zero-hours jobs, 9 September, 2013). However, the details of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research forecast (UK economy is expanding at the same rate as when coalition came to power, 7 September) show that, despite real GDP being 6% higher, real personal disposable income will be about 1% lower in 2015 than in 2010. The difference is partly explained by the UK's population growth, but the key point is that GDP is not the same as household income – which is what matters for living standards. Headlines should reflect what is happening to household real incomes, rather than the usually quoted GDP figures.
Professor Tony Atkinson
Oxford

• On 9 September you published a number of pieces discussing new economic data indicating the possibility of recovery, and that this would only be a true recovery once wages started to rise.

My experience, through undertaking a great deal of market research throughout the recession, shows that most households are looking for an economic recovery to provide greater job security and certainty of income. This allows people to contemplate new expenditure, as they feel confident that there will be the money to pay for it. So, while extra money would obviously be good, this isn't the first priority.

Meanwhile, businesses are reluctant to engage in wage rises as high employment costs irrevocably increase a business's cost base to the detriment of corporate manoeuvrability – when times become tough then the only option becomes layoffs or closure. Instead, bonuses and other rewards are in place to share in the success of the employer, which can be varied in line with performance.

Given this. I find your underlying editorial assumption that wages must rise to demonstrate economic recovery shockingly naive, if not a bit old-fashioned. Germany has demonstrated that economic strength and sustainability come, in part, from wage restraint: wages there have fallen in real terms every year since reunification.

Today's reality is that if you want to earn more you must seek new skills or job progression, not expect more money for doing the same.
Simon Rowland
London

• Karel Williams (Comment, 9 September) is right: our unbalanced economy means that London's continued good fortune does not represent a national recovery. There are persistent regional inequalities. As he says, labels are important. It's a shame therefore that he doesn't explicitly refer to other ways in which our economy could be perceived as "unbalanced", such as the size of financial services in relation to other sectors. Not only are these other meanings important in their own right for our understanding of the economy, we also need to be vigilant to political discourse on our "unbalanced economy" and proposals to "rebalance" it, such as HS2 (a project not referred to by Williams).

If HS2 really can help "rebalance" our economy (Letters, 9 September), it's essential that the public understands exactly how our current economy is "unbalanced". Politicians should not hide behind ambiguity.
Dr Alex May
Manchester

• Polly Toynbee, as always, hits the nail on the head, when she writes: "If competition over living standards for low and middle earners becomes the next battleground, it's cause for celebration" (Whose recovery is this?, Comment, 7 September). The Labour party conference should be a real opportunity to promote policy measures that will reduce income inequality and to demonstrate the political commitment to implement such policy measures. The living wage needs to be an expectation, zero-hours contracts should be outlawed (unless it is a personal choice). What is needed is to stop the race to the bottom for wages and living standards of those already poor, and the race to the top for those living in the 'wealth bubble'. Maybe Labour's rallying cry should be: "No ifs, no buts, we are committed to paying the living wage, and that's a fact!"
Christina Kadir
Chair, Sussex Equality Group

webTitle: Icap to be fined for Libor rigging

fields.standfirst: Money broker run by ex-Tory party treasurer Michael Spencer in talks with regulators about scale of penalty
fields.body:
Money broker Icap is poised to become the fourth major financial services firm to be fined for rigging Libor and is facing fines of up to £70m from regulators on both sides of Atlantic.

Icap, run by the former Conservative party treasurer Michael Spencer, is in discussions with the Financial Conduct Authority and the US regulatory bodies about the scale of the penalty it will pay for manipulating the benchmark interest rate.

Confirmation of any fines is expected within a fortnight and could be followed in the coming months by regulatory action against three other firms still under investigation by the FCA, which has already fined Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland and UBS.

The settlement being discussed with Icap is likely to be considerably lower than the fines paid by the three banks – £290m for Barclays, £390m for RBS and £940m for UBS.

A report by Sky News of the potential size of the fine sparked a 5% rise in Icap shares, which were the largest riser in the FTSE 250 index. The shares closed at 417.8p, up 4.5%.

Icap is the world's largest broker for major banks in the money markets but does not sit on the panels used to set Libor, which has undergone an overhaul since the Barclays fine in June 2012 led to scrutiny of the way it was set. Icap has also insisted that none of its senior management were ever aware of or involved in improper activities about manipulating Libor, which is used to price £200tn or products around the world.

It has previously said one member of staff has been suspended and three placed on administrative leave.

From next year, Libor – formally the London interbank offered rate – will be overseen by the body that runs the New York stock exchange rather than the British Bankers' Association. It was originally set by a panel of banks being asked the price at which they expect to borrow over 15 periods, from overnight to 12 months, in 10 currencies. The number of currencies has been reduced to five and rates published over seven borrowing periods.

webTitle: FRC judgment on Deloitte over MG Rover could carry positive implications | Nils Pratley

fields.bodyText: Deloitte's response to being fined £14m by the Financial Reporting Council, and seeing one of its former partners banned from the profession for three years, is extraordinary. Remember the background here. Some 6,000 car workers lost their jobs when MG Rover collapsed in 2005. The so-called Phoenix Four, the businessmen who turned out not to be saviours of the firm, had collected £42m, partly through the use of complex schemes that Deloitte helped to execute. The four, damned by a government report in 2009, were later disqualified as company directors. The FRC identified a "persistent and deliberate disregard" of accountancy ethics on the part of Deloitte and Maghsoud Einollahi. The regulator's report details Deloitte's conflict of interest during its work for various parts of the MG Rover group. Rather than apologise, though, Deloitte wants to argue. It is "disappointed" by the ruling and advances this argument: "This [finding] could have negative implications for the advice that can be provided by ICAEW [The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England & Wales] member firms and members, both within the profession and business". Negative implications? Well, it depends where you're sitting. From Deloitte's point of view, yes, it would be nice to inhabit a simple world where corporate advisers can merely advise their clients. But the rest of us would like to have an accountancy and advisory industry capable of judging when clients' interests and the public interest diverge. The FRC ruling sounds like it carries positive implications. Of course, judgements will rarely be straightforward in practice. But MG Rover, surely, was a company where there was a duty on Deloitte to act with extra diligence. The government had been involved with the rescue of a firm that was the last big British-owned carmaker. Rather than grumbling, Deloitte should accept with good grace the findings of a regulator charged with promoting good corporate governance. Alternatively, Deloitte's partners are free to find some other line of work.

It is "disappointed" by the ruling and advances this argument: "This [finding] could have negative implications for the advice that can be provided by ICAEW [The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England & Wales] member firms and members, both within the profession and business".

Negative implications? Well, it depends where you're sitting. From Deloitte's point of view, yes, it would be nice to inhabit a simple world where corporate advisers can merely advise their clients. But the rest of us would like to have an accountancy and advisory industry capable of judging when clients' interests and the public interest diverge. The FRC ruling sounds like it carries positive implications.

Of course, judgements will rarely be straightforward in practice. But MG Rover, surely, was a company where there was a duty on Deloitte to act with extra diligence.

The government had been involved with the rescue of a firm that was the last big British-owned carmaker.

Rather than grumbling, Deloitte should accept with good grace the findings of a regulator charged with promoting good corporate governance. Alternatively, Deloitte's partners are free to find some other line of work.

webTitle: Japanese GDP revised upwards

fields.standfirst: Nikkei jumps as second-quarter economic growth estimate revised from 0.6% to 0.9%
fields.body:
Tokyo's Olympic triumph was followed on Monday by good news from the Japanese economy after official figures showed GDP grew faster than previously estimated in the early part of the summer.

The Nikkei index jumped 2.5% in response to a rise in GDP from 0.6% in the three months to the end of June to a revised 0.9% that put the annualised rate at 3.8%.

Analysts said the rocketing economy was testament to the new political regime under prime minister Shinzo Abe, who has given his name to the Abenomics shock treatment his administration has delivered to the economy following his election last year.

Since October 2012 the Nikkei has soared from 8,500 to 15,000 before falling back to 13,500. In the last fortnight the index has regained some momentum and begun to head back towards 14,000 again.

While the index is still well below the 38,000 it registered in the 1980s boom, and its pre-Lehmans crash peak of 18,100, the stock market rise over the last year is seen as an indication of Abe's determination to inject some life into the economy and spur growth.

The upward revision in the last GDP figures appears to vindicate his policies – which have included appointing a new central bank governor with a remit to loosen monetary policy and backing from the finance ministry for large scale public infrastructure projects.

Nancy Curtin, chief investment officer at Close Brothers Asset Management, said it was clear that the world's third largest economy is heading in the right direction: "The red carpet was rolled out last week for Japan's strengthened Q2 GDP figures when the Bank of Japan announced expectations for inflation are improving.

"But it is not the only sign of recovery as a result of Shinzo Abe's initial shock and awe approach. Amid strong indications that exports and fixed asset investments are picking up, public investment is rising and the housing sector looks even more robust."

However, more detailed figures showed that Japan has become reliant on public and business investment when analysts were hoping for a revival in consumer spending. Private consumption was revised down from 0.8% to 0.7% quarter on quarter and consumer confidence slipped slightly.

Capital Economics said consumers were cutting back on spending after becoming worried that wages will fail to keep pace with inflation.

The latest Economic Watchers Survey offset good news from the manufacturing sector with a fifth consecutive drop in its index of current economic conditions from 52.3 in July to 51.2 in August.

webTitle: A decent outcome as leveraged buyout brigade outbid for Ribena and Lucozade | Nils Pratley

fields.bodyText: In the pre-crash days, the hot favourite to buy Ribena and Lucozade would have been a private equity group, or groups. The two drinks seem to have many financial characteristics that typically attract the leveraged buyout brigade – strong brands, stable turnover, high profit margins and well-invested assets. Gear up that little lot with a pile of cheap debt, squeeze the cash flows harder than the blackcurrants, and the financial gymnastics might prove very worthwhile. But it hasn't turned out that way. The winner of the auction conducted by GlaxoSmithKline is a trade buyer – Suntory, the Japanese whisky and soft drinks group. Private equity firms were in the race but were outbid. A sign of private equity's reduced firepower? Maybe, but the other factor was probably Suntory's desperation to expand outside Japan and to add its Orangina Schweppes purchase a few years ago. The result for GSK is a price that looks pretty on all main measures. Suntory is paying 2.6 times turnover and about 14 times profits, assuming Ribena's and Lucozade's margins are roughly in line with the average for GSK's consumer brands. The Japanese also bring less risk for GSK in the sense that they are more likely to invest in the business over the long-term rather than play financial games. Suntory, for example, was happy to sign a three-year protection agreement on the Coleford manufacturing plant in the Forest of Dean. We'll wait to see what happens after the three years are up, but this looks to be a decent outcome all round.

webTitle: Eurozone investor confidence leaps, but happiness slumps - as it happened

fields.bodyText: Europe's stock markets have closed for the day. Italy's FTSE MIB posted the biggest rise of the main indices, up over 1% on relief that the coalition government had not been rocked (yet) by the Berlusconi panic. Other markets ended flat, or down, with the Syrian crisis continuing to drive caution in the City. Closing prices: • FTSE 100: down 16 points at 6530, -0.25% • German DAX: flat at 8276 • French CAC: down 8 points at 4040, -0.2% • Spanish IBEX: down 22 points at 8,632, - 0.26% • Italian FTSE MIB: up 197 points at 17,244, +1.16% And in the currency markets, the pound has gained almost one cent against the US dollar to $1.5712, partly due to George Osborne's bullish speech this morning. Chris Beauchamp, market analyst at IG, points out that the encouraging news from Asia overnight (Japanese GDP revised higher, and forecast-beating Chinese exports) had little impact on London shares; Signs of life in China failed to buoy the mining sector in any meaningful fashion, with the sector showing a distinctly mixed performance. Rio Tinto and Anglo American were in the ascendant, but BHP and Antofagasta refused to join in the general rejoicing among raw materials firms. Sentiment was hit by a sharp drop in BG Group shares, as the firm warned that troubles in Egypt would hit production while its Norway efforts would not bear fruit as early as hoped. The company’s protestations of better times to come fell on deaf ears, and the shares lost 5.3%. Here's the biggest fallers on the FTSE 100 tonight: While City brokerage ICAP was the biggest riser on the FTSE 250 index - following that report that it faces a £70m Libor fine (see 2.01pm). That suggests £70m would be a good result for the firm.... And on that note, I'm off. Back tomorrow. Thanks all, and goodnight. GW This video, by the crisis-scape.net team, records how migrants in Greece have been subject to more attacks, and arrests, since the financial crisis began: The team are also recording examples of such attacks here: map.crisis-scape.net A new survey of world happiness, conducted by the UN, had found that the four eurozone countries at the heart of the debt crisis have become much less pleasant places to live. The survey, published today, confirmed what many blog readers have long reported – that happiness has deteriorated across the eurozone periphery. Greece suffered the most, coming second only to Egypt in terms of the drop in happiness over the last year. Spain came sixth for deteriorating happiness, followed by Italy in 8th place and Portugal in 12th. The lengthy report (156 pages, online here) said the drop in happiness was "far greater" than would be expected from just the drop in incomes since the crisis began. Instead, soaring unemployment and the restrictions on "life choices" are the key reasons. The report explains: The biggest hit, in terms of the implied drop in life evaluations, was in respondents’ perceived freedom to make key life choices. In each country the crisis tended to limit opportunities for individuals, both through cutbacks in available services and loss of expected opportunities. Portugal's drop in happiness was entirely due to the jobless crisis, the report found, while other issues such as 'perceived rising corruption' and disintegrating social fabric were responsible for tumbling happiness in the other three countries, as this chart from the report shows: Greece came in 70th overall for happiness in the report, with Portugal at 85, Italy at 45 and Spain at 38. The report also suggests that the striking slump in happiness in Greece is because people have dramatically lost faith in the country's institutions - namely the police and the legal system. It explains: Although generalized social trust is maintained roughly at pre-crisis levels, trust in police and in the legal system fall much more in Greece. Trust in police stayed stable at pre-crisis levels, or even grew slightly, in Spain and Portugal, while falling by 25% in Greece. Trust in the legal system fell significantly in all three countries [Greece, Italy and Spain], but by almost three times as much in Greece as in the other countries. And Greece's eKathimerini newspaper flags up another bleak statistics -- that suicides in Greece have doubled since the crisis began. It begins: A day ahead of World Suicide Prevention Day, reports suggest that the doubling of the number of suicides in Greece in the three-year period between 2009 and 2011 represents a trend that shows no sign of abating this year. Combined data by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT), the Citizens' Protection Ministry and the European statistical agency Eurostat show that Greece went from being one of the countries with the smallest number of suicides in the world to seeing suicides double in the three years between 2009 and 2011. The number of deaths by suicide rose from 2.5 per 100,000 of the population before 2009 to over five per 100,000, or 1,245 in the three-year period during which the country was hit by a combination of deep recession and tough austerity measures. Over in Rome, Italian politicians are considing whether Silvio Berlusconi should be barred from the Senate following the failure of his final appeal against a tax fraud charge. As explained at 9.53am, there are fears that Berlusconi could withdraw his People of Liberty (PDL) from the coalition government unless he is reprieved (he's even filed an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights) . Senators are unlikely to take a decision today. Committee member Benedetto della Vedova (who represents Mario Monti's centrist Civic Choice party) has told La Repubblica that it could take "weeks, not days" for the legal issues to be hammered out, adding: But that doesn't mean accepting any delaying tactics. In Italy? Perish the very thought. Meanwhile the Italy Chronicles blog is scathing of the political classes for not dealing with the former prime minister. Here's a flavour: Really, in the view of this Italy observer, the parliamentary commission is completely unnecessary. Berlusconi has been convicted of a crime and he should be removed from parliament automatically with out any vote. Had Italy’s government been in the hands of a Berlusconi coalition, the vote would have been in his favor, thus making a mockery of Italian law and the nation’s constitution. It is not known when the vote on Berlusconi’s parliamentary future will take place, though it is expected before the end of September. If the vote goes against Berlusconi, his immunity from arrest will be removed. This worries Berlusconi considerably as he fears he will be arrested sooner or later, possibly in connection with accusations, confirmed by another senator, of alleged bribery. Rumors that an arrest warrant for Berlusconi has been prepared have been denied by magistrates leading the senator bribery investigation. More here: Stripping Berlusconi Sky News is reporting that ICAP, the world's largest interdealer broker, could be close to paying a £70m fine for its role in the Libor scandal. We've known for some time that ICAP was in talks with US and UK regulators over the affair, in which workers on several trading desks helped to fix the official rate at which banks would lend to each other. But it's the first time that a possible settlement figure has been reported. Via Sky News: One insider said on Monday that ICAP, which is run by Michael Spencer, one of the City's wealthiest men, was closer to finalising a settlement with the FCA than with the US regulators. The civil settlement will be an embarrassment to Mr Spencer, who has consistently sought to downplay the extent of ICAP's involvement in the manipulation of Libor. However, a deal costing the interdealer broker in the region of £70m would not be financially material to ICAP and would be only marginally higher than the projections of City analysts. Spencer is also a former Treasurer of the Conservative Party. A £70m fine would be lower than Barclays (£290m) or Royal Bank of Scotland (£390m). It'd be interesting to see if the payment was imposed on the company's bonus pool, as happened with RBS (which is mostly owned by the UK taxpaper). The World Trade Organisation isn't getting carried away by this talk of economic revival. It just cut its forecasts for trade growth, due to Europe's weak economy: The WTO now expects world trade this year to expand by 2.5%, down from 3.3%. It has also lowered its 2014 forecast to 4.5%, from 5%. Reuters has more details: World trade is expected to grow by 2.5% this year and 4.5% in 2014, the World Trade Organization's new chief Roberto Azevedo said on Monday, revising down previous estimates of 3.3% and 5%. Azevedo said the figures will be detailed in a report to be released on September 19. He said the forecasts had been cut because the European Union had been expected to recover in the second quarter of this year, but was now expected to bottom out in the third quarter. Following the sale of Ribena and Lucozade this morning (see 9am) we're pulled together a list of other British food and drink brands that are now owned by overseas firms. From Cadbury to Newcastle Brown Ale, via Weetabix and Branston Pickle, it's a pantry-worth of kitchen favourites: A taste of Britain: UK brands sold overseas Duncan Weldon, senior policy advisor at the TUC (and long-time critic of George Osborne's handling of the economy), isn't convinced by today's speech: Via Andrew Sparrow's liveblog: Here's the full text of George Osborne's speech. And here's the press notice the Treasury has issued. Looking back at Japan, Fung Siu of the Economist Intelligence Unit confirms that Tokyo is hoping for an economic boost from the 2020 Olympics (as mentioned in my opening post at 7.54am), but explains that it may not be felt until 2017: The prime minister has already declared that hosting the Olympics is the fourth arrow of Abenomics. Hosting the games will help boost economic growth in the medium to long-term. The Japanese government is unlikely to launch a complete overhaul of the city's infrastructure. Part of the reason why Tokyo won the bid was because the city's infrastructure was in such good order (compared with the other bids) so the decision is unlikely to impact growth in the short-term. Preparations for the games are likely to begin in earnest from 2017 when there might be a slight increase in real GDP growth. Hosting the games will certainly help keep Japanese economy on a sustainable growth path over the medium to long-term. One more key line from Osborne – he defended the Bank of England's new 'forward guidance' that UK interest rates aren't going up anytime soon. The chancellor argues that it's wrong to suggest that the guidance has failed because yields on UK government bonds have since risen to a 2-year high (the 10-year yield hit 3% last week). Quite the reverse, he says - rising yields are a sign of confidence in Britain's recovery, which "vindicates" the need for forward guidance. The 'counterfactual' is that rates would be even higher without the Bank's new pledge, given all the recent signs that the UK economy is healing. Hang on, though -- it's not that long ago that Osborne was hailing record low bond yields as a sign of faith in Britain's economy.... The nub of George Osborne's speech today (full coverage here on Politics Live) is that those who called for an additional fiscal stimulus to stimulate growth, a Plan B, have "lost the argument", and are the "biggest threat to the economy today". Osborne's argument is that the UK's economic underperformance since he took office is due to the shock of higher inflation, the eurozone crisis, and the resulting impact on financial conditions. Not the shock of his austerity measures. Thus, growth has returned in recent months as those threats eased. Osborne gives the European Central bank some credit, saying the eurozone crisis has "abated" following the ECB's actions last summer. In other news, Osborne is also sporting a back-to-school haircut: Chancellor George Osborne has begun his speech on the UK economy in London. As expected, Osborne is arguing that his 'plan A' has pulled the UK out of the crisis, and slamming his critics. The economic collapse was even worse than the thought. Repairing it will take longer than we hoped....but we held our nerve when many urged us to change course. Thanks to the efforts of firms and households, we have turned the corner, Osborne declared. He's now outlining how the UK suffered so badly in the Great Recession because the banking sector had been allowed to expand out out of control, and because public spending rose steadily through the boom years before the credit crunch. "Truly sustainable" growth in future, he argues, will depend on 'sound public finances' and well-capitalised banks. My colleague Andrew Sparrow will be covering the whole speech in Politics Live. Confidence over the European recovery continues to rise, with the news this morning that eurozone investors are more optimistic about the situation than any time in the last two years. Sentix's index of eurozone sentiment came in positively for the first time in more than two years in September, with investors saying they are more upbeat about the outlook for Europe. Its monthly reading came in at +6.5 points, the highest reading since May 2011, and up from August's -4.9 points. That's the second-biggest month-on-month improvement since the survey began in 2003, as the graph above shows: Dr Sebastian Wanke, Sentix's senior analyst, called the reading: an explosive coup for the euro zone adding that it was driven by rising confidence in Germany. He said: For Germany, the composite index jumped upward, too, and reached its highest reading since April 2011 which signals a clearly strengthening economy. Good news all round, but also a reminder that sentiment could quickly sour if the recovery should stumble. Last week the ECB trimmed its eurozone growth forecast for 2014 to just 1%, so there's not much leeway. Sentix also warned that sovereign bond prices are expected to fall in the months ahead, pushing up the cost of government borrowing. That's because, "according to investors, neither central bank policies nor the economy will have a positive influence on bond prices". Just in: Greece's industrial production is still shrinking, while shop prices remain locked in deflation. New data shows that industrial output dropped by 8.1% year-on-year in July, reversing the 0.6% rise recorded in June. Manufacturing output dropped by 4.3%, while there was a 19.6% plunge in electricity production. As this graph shows, Greece's industrial base is a fifth smaller than before the financial crisis began [more details here] And while prime minister Samaras talks about 'the worst being over' (see 9.38am), retailers are still being forced to slash prices. Consumer prices fell by 1.3% in August, year-on-year, showing deflation is accelerating after July's -0.7% reading. Data last week showed that the fall in Greek GDP was slowing, thanks to a surge in tourism this year. Speaking of Italy, bad debts within its banking sector jumped by 22% year-on-year in July, the latest sign that its economy is deteriorating. The data, from the Bank of Italy, also showed that the Italian credit market remained disfunctional. Loans to households were down by 1.1% during the month, compared with July 2012, while the average interest rate charged to companies borrowing up to €1m rose from 4.3% to 4.41%. Eurocrisis watch (2): The political crisis in Italy will continue today as a Senate committee meets to consider whether to expel Silvio Berluconi from parliament, following his tax fraud conviction. Tension is high, as Berlusconi's allies say he could bring the country's shaky coalition crashing down, should he be banished from the Senate (as Italian law appears to demand). However, the great survivor of Italian politics could hang on a little longer, with member of Berlusconi's PDL party arguing that he should be spared...for a little longer at least. Reuters has the latest: Berlusconi's lawyers argue that the "Severino law", under which convicted politicians are ineligible for parliament, cannot apply in Berlusconi's case because it was passed last year. Berlusconi's lawyers have appealed to the European Court of Human Rights. They want the Senate committee to postpone proceedings until the European Court decides or Italy's constitutional court rules on whether the law is valid. That possibility has been rejected by the PD, which accuses the PDL of trying to waste time with groundless appeals. As the manoeuvres continue, President Giorgio Napolitano, who has played a decisive behind-the-scenes role in Italian politics since the Berlusconi crisis erupted, may play a significant part again. The meeting starts at 3pm local time (2pm BST)... Eurocrisis watch (1): Over the weekend, Greece's prime minister promised the long-suffering Greek people that the recession will soon (finally) be over. Antonis Samaras made the pledge at the annual Thessaloniki trade fair, as our Athens correspondent Helena Smith writes: Boosted by figures showing the economy contracting by 3.8% in the second quarter – its smallest decline since the outbreak of Athens's worst financial crisis in modern times – the leader said the country's dependency on foreign lenders was also nearing an end. "Greece is turning a page … all the international organisations agree that next year, 2014, will be the year of recovery for the Greek economy," he told industry and business leaders attending the annual Thessaloniki trade fair. "Last year most abroad were predicting that Greece would exit the euro. Now they are predicting the exact opposite. That Greece will exit the recession and stay in the euro," he said promising that the progress would hail the end of unpopular austerity. Here's Helena's full story: Worst of Greece's recession is nearly over, says prime minister There was no mention of another aid package for Greece, which some analysts believe will need to be hammered out his autumn. And opposition to Greece's austerity programme has not dissolved. On Saturday night, a demonstration organised by trade unions outside the Trade Fair building was well-attended. And some young demonstrators were detained by police officers after minor clashes broke out: In the corporate world two childhood favourites, Ribena and Lucozade, are changing hands. Japan's Suntory Beverage & Food is taking control of both brands, having just agreed to pay £1.35bn for GSK's soft drinks portfolio (details here). David Redfern, chief strategy officer at GSK, said the deal would help his firm focus on healthcare and pharmaceuticals. He insists that both brands should be safe once the deal goes through: Lucozade and Ribena are iconic brands that have made a huge contribution to GSK over the years, but now is the right time to sell them as we increase the focus of our Consumer Healthcare business and execute the delivery of our late stage pipeline of pharmaceuticals and vaccines. We believe the future of Lucozade and Ribena is in good hands given SBF's established beverages business, ambitious growth plans and also their recognition of the strong performance and capability of the GSK employees working on these products. Reassuring to know that poorly children will still be nursed through a nasty cold with a soothing mug of hot Ribena in future years. The sale is part of a trend of classic British food brands being devoured by foreign investors -- including KP Nuts, Sarson's vinegar and Weetabix. The BBC has rounded up some media reaction to George Osborne's upcoming speech on the economy (which my colleague Andrew Sparrow will cover extensively in his Politics Live blog): • The Financial Times says it helps him consolidate his stewardship of Britain's finances ahead of the party conferences. • The Daily Express says his star is rising, and he is widely seen as Prime Minister David Cameron's successor. • But the Sun has doubts about his assertions. It praises the chancellor for sticking to his policy guns but it says the good news is "just numbers" and that "people don't feel better off". • The Daily Mirror calls him "complacent" and "boastful". More here. In Britain, chancellor George Osborne will declare today that the UK economy has "turned the corner", and that critics of his plans have been defeated. Our political editor Patrick Wintour has the details: "Even if the improving economic news eventually leads to an improvement in the fiscal outlook, the job will not be done," he will say in a major speech aimed at setting the parameters of the 2015 election. "More tough choices will be required after the next election to find many billions of further savings." A bullish chancellor will claim that critics of his deficit reduction plans are at a loss to explain why the recovery is now taking place. He will point out that the spending cuts are at their deepest now owing to the backloading of the cuts programme. He will point to evidence that shows in his view "the last few months have decisively ended [the] controversy" about fiscal policy – as those who advocate a so-called plan B cannot explain recent improvements in the economic data. He will say that if he had heeded the advice of the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, to spend and borrow more, it would have undermined the recovery. Instead he will claim he held his nerve, and that the economy is now recovering. Britain's economy does, indeed, seem to be growing robustly at present – with GDP rising by 0.7% between April and June. Many economists reckon it picked up pace over the summer. But, with real wages still lagging behind inflation, it does not feel like a recovery to many people. The Labour opposition will hammer this point home today, when Ed Miliband pledges to crack down on zero-hours contracts (where workers aren't guaranteed any minimum paid work). Ed Miliband vows to get tough on zero-hours contracts Spain's IBEX is the worst-performing index in Europe this morning, down almost 1% after Madrid missed out (again) on hosting the Olympics. Although the economic benefits of hosting the Olympics aren't clear, the Spanish must be gutted to be rebuffed for the third time. As my colleague Paul Hamilos writes: And so it was that on Sunday morning, Madrid woke up to the hangover of an economy that continues in crisis, youth unemployment at record levels of 56%, and little to look forward to. The news dominated the headlines on TV and in the papers. "The great disappointment," shouted the front page of El Mundo newspaper, while ABC said "Goodbye to the Olympic dream". 2020 Olympics: Madrid disappointed for third time Today's upwardly revised GDP data shows Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe's first two "arrows" - monetary and fiscal stimulus - are hitting their target, argued Rob Wood of Berenberg. However, how about arrow 3 -- structural reforms? No sign of a bullseye yet, Wood says: The signs so far have been disappointing, raising the risks that this spurt of growth in Japan will fizzle out after a year or two. Still, Abe has the opportunity to announce root and branch reforms that would increase competition in parts of Japan’s closeted economy and unleash better productivity growth. He just needs to seize the opportunity as he did with the stimulus. The Japanese Nikkei has closed at a five-week high as the Tokyo stock market enjoyed an Olympics bounce today. Shares rose as traders anticipated increased spending ahead of 2020, and also welcomed the news that Japan's economy grew faster than thought in Q2. The Nikkei surged 2.5%, or 344 points, to 14,205, while the Hong Kong the Hang Seng was up 0.5%. As Nobuhiko Karamochi of Muzuho Securities explained: The GDP data overall was strong, and companies' capital spending in particular stood out. Although we were already assuming that corporate investment would be strong, given recent capital investment data for the April-June quarter, this should bolster sentiment. Asian investors also welcomed the news that China's exports beat exports in August, up 7.2% year-on-year. No bounce in Europe, though, where the main indices are mostly in the red (FTSE 100 down 5 points, and Spain's IBEX shedding 0.8% in early trading). Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. The week begins with bullish news from Asia, where Japan's economy grew much faster between April and June than first thought. A surge in capital expenditure drove GDP up by 3.8% on an annualised basis (or more than +0.9% quarter-on-quarter), the Cabinet Office reported, up from the first estimate of 2.6%. It's the third successive quarterly rise, and may indicate that prime minister Abe's efforts to reflate the Japanese economy through government spending and a massive stimulus package, are working. Analysts said the cheery news should pave the way for Abe to hike the Japanese sales tax, an effort to push up revenues and make a (small) dent in Japan's debt mountain. Hiroako Muto, senior economist at Sumitomo Mitsui Asset Management, explained: Companies are replacing old equipment, which led to the large upward revision to GDP. fields.standfirst:
• UN Report: Greece, Portugal, Spain and Italy tumble on happiness index
• But investor confidence jumps
• Italian Senate considering Berlusconi’s fate
• Osborne claims success over UK economy
• Boost for Japanese as GDP revised upwards
fields.headline: Eurozone investor confidence leaps, but happiness slumps - as it happened
fields.body:
5.23pm BST

European stock markets close

Europe's stock markets have closed for the day.

Italy's FTSE MIB posted the biggest rise of the main indices, up over 1% on relief that the coalition government had not been rocked (yet) by the Berlusconi panic.

Other markets ended flat, or down, with the Syrian crisis continuing to drive caution in the City.

Closing prices:

• FTSE 100: down 16 points at 6530, -0.25%

• German DAX: flat at 8276

• French CAC: down 8 points at 4040, -0.2%

• Spanish IBEX: down 22 points at 8,632, - 0.26%

• Italian FTSE MIB: up 197 points at 17,244, +1.16%

And in the currency markets, the pound has gained almost one cent against the US dollar to $1.5712, partly due to George Osborne's bullish speech this morning.

Chris Beauchamp, market analyst at IG, points out that the encouraging news from Asia overnight (Japanese GDP revised higher, and forecast-beating Chinese exports) had little impact on London shares;

Signs of life in China failed to buoy the mining sector in any meaningful fashion, with the sector showing a distinctly mixed performance.

Rio Tinto and Anglo American were in the ascendant, but BHP and Antofagasta refused to join in the general rejoicing among raw materials firms.

Sentiment was hit by a sharp drop in BG Group shares, as the firm warned that troubles in Egypt would hit production while its Norway efforts would not bear fruit as early as hoped. The company’s protestations of better times to come fell on deaf ears, and the shares lost 5.3%.

Here's the biggest fallers on the FTSE 100 tonight:

While City brokerage ICAP was the biggest riser on the FTSE 250 index - following that report that it faces a £70m Libor fine (see 2.01pm). That suggests £70m would be a good result for the firm....

And on that note, I'm off. Back tomorrow. Thanks all, and goodnight. GW

Updated at 5.28pm BST

4.30pm BST

This video, by the crisis-scape.net team, records how migrants in Greece have been subject to more attacks, and arrests, since the financial crisis began: 

The team are also recording examples of such attacks here: map.crisis-scape.net

4.08pm BST

UN: Unhappiness slides in eurozone crisis countries

A new survey of world happiness, conducted by the UN, had found that the four eurozone countries at the heart of the debt crisis have become much less pleasant places to live.

The survey, published today, confirmed what many blog readers have long reported – that happiness has deteriorated across the eurozone periphery.

Greece suffered the most, coming second only to Egypt in terms of the drop in happiness over the last year. Spain came sixth for deteriorating happiness, followed by Italy in 8th place and Portugal in 12th.

The lengthy report (156 pages, online here) said the drop in happiness was "far greater" than would be expected from just the drop in incomes since the crisis began. Instead, soaring unemployment and the restrictions on "life choices" are the key reasons.

The report explains:

The biggest hit, in terms of the implied drop in life evaluations, was in respondents’ perceived freedom to make key life choices.

In each country the crisis tended to limit opportunities for individuals, both through cutbacks in available services and loss of expected opportunities.

Portugal's drop in happiness was entirely due to the jobless crisis, the report found, while other issues such as 'perceived rising corruption' and disintegrating social fabric were responsible for tumbling happiness in the other three countries, as this chart from the report shows:

Greece came in 70th overall for happiness in the report, with Portugal at 85, Italy at 45 and Spain at 38.

The report also suggests that the striking slump in happiness in Greece is because people have dramatically lost faith in the country's institutions - namely the police and the legal system.

It explains:

Although generalized social trust is maintained roughly at pre-crisis levels, trust in police and in the legal system fall much more in Greece.

Trust in police stayed stable at pre-crisis levels, or even grew slightly, in Spain and Portugal, while falling by 25% in Greece. 

Trust in the legal system fell significantly in all three countries [Greece, Italy and Spain], but by almost three times as much in Greece as in the other countries.

And Greece's eKathimerini newspaper flags up another bleak statistics -- that suicides in Greece have doubled since the crisis began.

It begins:

A day ahead of World Suicide Prevention Day, reports suggest that the doubling of the number of suicides in Greece in the three-year period between 2009 and 2011 represents a trend that shows no sign of abating this year.

Combined data by the Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT), the Citizens' Protection Ministry and the European statistical agency Eurostat show that Greece went from being one of the countries with the smallest number of suicides in the world to seeing suicides double in the three years between 2009 and 2011.

The number of deaths by suicide rose from 2.5 per 100,000 of the population before 2009 to over five per 100,000, or 1,245 in the three-year period during which the country was hit by a combination of deep recession and tough austerity measures. 

Updated at 4.09pm BST

2.44pm BST

Over in Rome, Italian politicians are considing whether Silvio Berlusconi should be barred from the Senate following the failure of his final appeal against a tax fraud charge.

As explained at 9.53am, there are fears that Berlusconi could withdraw his People of Liberty (PDL) from the coalition government unless he is reprieved (he's even filed an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights) .

Senators are unlikely to take a decision today. Committee member Benedetto della Vedova (who represents Mario Monti's centrist Civic Choice party) has told La Repubblica that it could take "weeks, not days" for the legal issues to be hammered out, adding:

But that doesn't mean accepting any delaying tactics.

In Italy? Perish the very thought.

Meanwhile the Italy Chronicles blog is scathing of the political classes for not dealing with the former prime minister. Here's a flavour:

Really, in the view of this Italy observer, the parliamentary commission is completely unnecessary. Berlusconi has been convicted of a crime and he should be removed from parliament automatically with out any vote.

Had Italy’s government been in the hands of a Berlusconi coalition, the vote would have been in his favor, thus making a mockery of Italian law and the nation’s constitution. It is not known when the vote on Berlusconi’s parliamentary future will take place, though it is expected before the end of September.

If the vote goes against Berlusconi, his immunity from arrest will be removed.

This worries Berlusconi considerably as he fears he will be arrested sooner or later, possibly in connection with accusations, confirmed by another senator, of alleged bribery. Rumors that an arrest warrant for Berlusconi has been prepared have been denied by magistrates leading the senator bribery investigation. 

More here: Stripping Berlusconi

Updated at 2.45pm BST

2.01pm BST

Sky News is reporting that ICAP, the world's largest interdealer broker, could be close to paying a £70m fine for its role in the Libor scandal.

We've known for some time that ICAP was in talks with US and UK regulators over the affair, in which workers on several trading desks helped to fix the official rate at which banks would lend to each other. But it's the first time that a possible settlement figure has been reported.

Via Sky News:

One insider said on Monday that ICAP, which is run by Michael Spencer, one of the City's wealthiest men, was closer to finalising a settlement with the FCA than with the US regulators.

The civil settlement will be an embarrassment to Mr Spencer, who has consistently sought to downplay the extent of ICAP's involvement in the manipulation of Libor.

However, a deal costing the interdealer broker in the region of £70m would not be financially material to ICAP and would be only marginally higher than the projections of City analysts.

Spencer is also a former Treasurer of the Conservative Party.

A £70m fine would be lower than Barclays (£290m) or Royal Bank of Scotland (£390m). It'd be interesting to see if the payment was imposed on the company's bonus pool, as happened with RBS (which is mostly owned by the UK taxpaper).

1.11pm BST

WTO cuts growth forecasts

The World Trade Organisation isn't getting carried away by this talk of economic revival. It just cut its forecasts for trade growth, due to Europe's weak economy:

The WTO now expects world trade this year to expand by 2.5%, down from 3.3%. It has also lowered its 2014 forecast to 4.5%, from 5%.

Reuters has more details:

World trade is expected to grow by 2.5% this year and 4.5% in 2014, the World Trade Organization's new chief Roberto Azevedo said on Monday, revising down previous estimates of 3.3% and 5%.

Azevedo said the figures will be detailed in a report to be released on September 19. He said the forecasts had been cut because the European Union had been expected to recover in the second quarter of this year, but was now expected to bottom out in the third quarter.

Updated at 1.11pm BST

12.29pm BST

Following the sale of Ribena and Lucozade this morning (see 9am) we're pulled together a list of other British food and drink brands that are now owned by overseas firms.

From Cadbury to Newcastle Brown Ale, via Weetabix and Branston Pickle, it's a pantry-worth of kitchen favourites:

A taste of Britain: UK brands sold overseas

12.28pm BST

Duncan Weldon, senior policy advisor at the TUC (and long-time critic of George Osborne's handling of the economy), isn't convinced by today's speech:

Updated at 12.59pm BST

12.27pm BST

Via Andrew Sparrow's liveblog:

Here's the full text of George Osborne's speech.

And here's the press notice the Treasury has issued.

12.14pm BST

Looking back at Japan, Fung Siu of the Economist Intelligence Unit confirms that Tokyo is hoping for an economic boost from the 2020 Olympics (as mentioned in my opening post at 7.54am), but explains that it may not be felt until 2017:

The prime minister has already declared that hosting the Olympics is the fourth arrow of Abenomics. Hosting the games will help boost economic growth in the medium to long-term.

The Japanese government is unlikely to launch a complete overhaul of the city's infrastructure. Part of the reason why Tokyo won the bid was because the city's infrastructure was in such good order (compared with the other bids) so the decision is unlikely to impact growth in the short-term.

Preparations for the games are likely to begin in earnest from 2017 when there might be a slight increase in real GDP growth. Hosting the games will certainly help keep Japanese economy on a sustainable growth path over the medium to long-term.

11.46am BST

One more key line from Osborne – he defended the Bank of England's new 'forward guidance' that UK interest rates aren't going up anytime soon.

The chancellor argues that it's wrong to suggest that the guidance has failed because yields on UK government bonds have since risen to a 2-year high (the 10-year yield hit 3% last week).

Quite the reverse, he says - rising yields are a sign of confidence in Britain's recovery, which "vindicates" the need for forward guidance. The 'counterfactual' is that rates would be even higher without the Bank's new pledge, given all the recent signs that the UK economy is healing.

Hang on, though -- it's not that long ago that Osborne was hailing record low bond yields as a sign of faith in Britain's economy....

Updated at 11.51am BST

11.36am BST

The nub of George Osborne's speech today (full coverage here on Politics Live) is that those who called for an additional fiscal stimulus to stimulate growth, a Plan B, have "lost the argument", and are the "biggest threat to the economy today".

Osborne's argument is that the UK's economic underperformance since he took office is due to the shock of higher inflation, the eurozone crisis, and the resulting impact on financial conditions. Not the shock of his austerity measures.

Thus, growth has returned in recent months as those threats eased. Osborne gives the European Central bank some credit, saying the eurozone crisis has "abated" following the ECB's actions last summer.

In other news, Osborne is also sporting a back-to-school haircut:

Updated at 11.36am BST

11.24am BST

11.22am BST

Osborne: we held our nerve over the economy

Chancellor George Osborne has begun his speech on the UK economy in London.

As expected, Osborne is arguing that his 'plan A' has pulled the UK out of the crisis, and slamming his critics. 

The economic collapse was even worse than the thought. Repairing it will take longer than we hoped....but we held our nerve when many urged us to change course.

Thanks to the efforts of firms and households, we have turned the corner, Osborne declared.

He's now outlining how the UK suffered so badly in the Great Recession because the banking sector had been allowed to expand out out of control, and because public spending rose steadily through the boom years before the credit crunch. 

"Truly sustainable" growth in future, he argues, will depend on 'sound public finances' and well-capitalised banks. 

My colleague Andrew Sparrow will be covering the whole speech in Politics Live.

11.07am BST

Eurozone investor confidence hits two-year high

Confidence over the European recovery continues to rise, with the news this morning that eurozone investors are more optimistic about the situation than any time in the last two years.

Sentix's index of eurozone sentiment came in positively for the first time in more than two years in September, with investors saying they are more upbeat about the outlook for Europe.

Its monthly reading came in at +6.5 points, the highest reading since May 2011, and up from August's -4.9 points. That's the second-biggest month-on-month improvement since the survey began in 2003, as the graph above shows:

Dr Sebastian Wanke, Sentix's senior analyst, called the reading:

an explosive coup for the euro zone 

 adding that it was driven by rising confidence in Germany. He said:

For Germany, the composite index jumped upward, too, and reached its highest reading since April 2011 which signals a clearly strengthening economy.

Good news all round, but also a reminder that sentiment could quickly sour if the recovery should stumble. Last week the ECB trimmed its eurozone growth forecast for 2014 to just 1%, so there's not much leeway.

Sentix also warned that sovereign bond prices are expected to fall in the months ahead, pushing up the cost of government borrowing. That's because, "according to investors, neither central bank policies nor the economy will have a positive influence on bond prices".

Updated at 11.09am BST

10.36am BST

In Greece, deflation and falling industrial output

Just in: Greece's industrial production is still shrinking, while shop prices remain locked in deflation.

New data shows that industrial output dropped by 8.1% year-on-year in July, reversing the 0.6% rise recorded in June. Manufacturing output dropped by 4.3%, while there was a 19.6% plunge in electricity production.

As this graph shows, Greece's industrial base is a fifth smaller than before the financial crisis began [more details here]

And while prime minister Samaras talks about 'the worst being over' (see 9.38am), retailers are still being forced to slash prices. Consumer prices fell by 1.3% in August, year-on-year, showing deflation is accelerating after July's -0.7% reading.

Data last week showed that the fall in Greek GDP was slowing, thanks to a surge in tourism this year. 

Updated at 10.40am BST

10.20am BST

Speaking of Italy, bad debts within its banking sector jumped by 22% year-on-year in July, the latest sign that its economy is deteriorating.

The data, from the Bank of Italy, also showed that the Italian credit market remained disfunctional. Loans to households were down by 1.1% during the month, compared with July 2012, while the average interest rate charged to companies borrowing up to €1m rose from 4.3% to 4.41%.

9.53am BST

Eurocrisis watch (2): The political crisis in Italy will continue today as a Senate committee meets to consider whether to expel Silvio Berluconi from parliament, following his tax fraud conviction.

Tension is high, as Berlusconi's allies say he could bring the country's shaky coalition crashing down, should he be banished from the Senate (as Italian law appears to demand).

However, the great survivor of Italian politics could hang on a little longer, with member of Berlusconi's PDL party arguing that he should be spared...for a little longer at least.

Reuters has the latest:

Berlusconi's lawyers argue that the "Severino law", under which convicted politicians are ineligible for parliament, cannot apply in Berlusconi's case because it was passed last year.

Berlusconi's lawyers have appealed to the European Court of Human Rights. They want the Senate committee to postpone proceedings until the European Court decides or Italy's constitutional court rules on whether the law is valid.

That possibility has been rejected by the PD, which accuses the PDL of trying to waste time with groundless appeals.

As the manoeuvres continue, President Giorgio Napolitano, who has played a decisive behind-the-scenes role in Italian politics since the Berlusconi crisis erupted, may play a significant part again.

The meeting starts at 3pm local time (2pm BST)...

9.38am BST

Eurocrisis watch (1): Over the weekend, Greece's prime minister promised the long-suffering Greek people that the recession will soon (finally) be over.

Antonis Samaras made the pledge at the annual Thessaloniki trade fair, as our Athens correspondent Helena Smith writes:

Boosted by figures showing the economy contracting by 3.8% in the second quarter – its smallest decline since the outbreak of Athens's worst financial crisis in modern times – the leader said the country's dependency on foreign lenders was also nearing an end.

"Greece is turning a page … all the international organisations agree that next year, 2014, will be the year of recovery for the Greek economy," he told industry and business leaders attending the annual Thessaloniki trade fair.

"Last year most abroad were predicting that Greece would exit the euro. Now they are predicting the exact opposite. That Greece will exit the recession and stay in the euro," he said promising that the progress would hail the end of unpopular austerity.

Here's Helena's full story: Worst of Greece's recession is nearly over, says prime minister

There was no mention of another aid package for Greece, which some analysts believe will need to be hammered out his autumn.

And opposition to Greece's austerity programme has not dissolved. On Saturday night, a demonstration organised by trade unions outside the Trade Fair building was well-attended.

And some young demonstrators were detained by police officers after minor clashes broke out:

Updated at 9.40am BST

9.20am BST

9.00am BST

Ribena and Lucozade switch hands

In the corporate world two childhood favourites, Ribena and Lucozade, are changing hands.

Japan's Suntory Beverage & Food is taking control of both brands, having just agreed to pay £1.35bn for GSK's soft drinks portfolio (details here).

David Redfern, chief strategy officer at GSK, said the deal would help his firm focus on healthcare and pharmaceuticals. He insists that both brands should be safe once the deal goes through:

Lucozade and Ribena are iconic brands that have made a huge contribution to GSK over the years, but now is the right time to sell them as we increase the focus of our Consumer Healthcare business and execute the delivery of our late stage pipeline of pharmaceuticals and vaccines. 

We believe the future of Lucozade and Ribena is in good hands given SBF's established beverages business, ambitious growth plans and also their recognition of the strong performance and capability of the GSK employees working on these products.

 Reassuring to know that poorly children will still be nursed through a nasty cold with a soothing mug of hot Ribena in future years.

 The sale is part of a trend of classic British food brands being devoured by foreign investors -- including KP Nuts, Sarson's vinegar and Weetabix. 

Updated at 9.18am BST

8.49am BST

The BBC has rounded up some media reaction to George Osborne's upcoming speech on the economy (which my colleague Andrew Sparrow will cover extensively in his Politics Live blog):

• The Financial Times says it helps him consolidate his stewardship of Britain's finances ahead of the party conferences.

• The Daily Express says his star is rising, and he is widely seen as Prime Minister David Cameron's successor.

• But the Sun has doubts about his assertions. It praises the chancellor for sticking to his policy guns but it says the good news is "just numbers" and that "people don't feel better off".

• The Daily Mirror calls him "complacent" and "boastful".

More here.

8.44am BST

Osborne to bang drum for UK economy

In Britain, chancellor George Osborne will declare today that the UK economy has "turned the corner", and that critics of his plans have been defeated.

Our political editor Patrick Wintour has the details:

"Even if the improving economic news eventually leads to an improvement in the fiscal outlook, the job will not be done," he will say in a major speech aimed at setting the parameters of the 2015 election. "More tough choices will be required after the next election to find many billions of further savings."

A bullish chancellor will claim that critics of his deficit reduction plans are at a loss to explain why the recovery is now taking place. He will point out that the spending cuts are at their deepest now owing to the backloading of the cuts programme.

He will point to evidence that shows in his view "the last few months have decisively ended [the] controversy" about fiscal policy – as those who advocate a so-called plan B cannot explain recent improvements in the economic data.

He will say that if he had heeded the advice of the shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, to spend and borrow more, it would have undermined the recovery. Instead he will claim he held his nerve, and that the economy is now recovering.

Britain's economy does, indeed, seem to be growing robustly at present – with GDP rising by 0.7% between April and June. Many economists reckon it picked up pace over the summer.

But, with real wages still lagging behind inflation, it does not feel like a recovery to many people. The Labour opposition will hammer this point home today, when Ed Miliband pledges to crack down on zero-hours contracts (where workers aren't guaranteed any minimum paid work).

Ed Miliband vows to get tough on zero-hours contracts

8.42am BST

Spain's IBEX is the worst-performing index in Europe this morning, down almost 1% after Madrid missed out (again) on hosting the Olympics. 

Although the economic benefits of hosting the Olympics aren't clear, the Spanish must be gutted to be rebuffed for the third time.

As my colleague Paul Hamilos writes:

And so it was that on Sunday morning, Madrid woke up to the hangover of an economy that continues in crisis, youth unemployment at record levels of 56%, and little to look forward to.

The news dominated the headlines on TV and in the papers. "The great disappointment," shouted the front page of El Mundo newspaper, while ABC said "Goodbye to the Olympic dream".

2020 Olympics: Madrid disappointed for third time

8.22am BST

Today's upwardly revised GDP data shows Japan's prime minister Shinzo Abe's first two "arrows" - monetary and fiscal stimulus - are hitting their target, argued Rob Wood of Berenberg.

However, how about arrow 3 -- structural reforms? No sign of a bullseye yet, Wood says:

The signs so far have been disappointing, raising the risks that this spurt of growth in Japan will fizzle out after a year or two.

Still, Abe has the opportunity to announce root and branch reforms that would increase competition in parts of Japan’s closeted economy and unleash better productivity growth. He just needs to seize the opportunity as he did with the stimulus.

8.15am BST

The Japanese Nikkei has closed at a five-week high as the Tokyo stock market enjoyed an Olympics bounce today.

Shares rose as traders anticipated increased spending ahead of 2020, and also welcomed the news that Japan's economy grew faster than thought in Q2.

The Nikkei surged 2.5%, or 344 points, to 14,205, while the Hong Kong the Hang Seng was up 0.5%.

As Nobuhiko Karamochi of Muzuho Securities explained:

The GDP data overall was strong, and companies' capital spending in particular stood out.

Although we were already assuming that corporate investment would be strong, given recent capital investment data for the April-June quarter, this should bolster sentiment.

Asian investors also welcomed the news that China's exports beat exports in August, up 7.2% year-on-year.

No bounce in Europe, though, where the main indices are mostly in the red (FTSE 100 down 5 points, and Spain's IBEX shedding 0.8% in early trading).

7.54am BST

Japanese GDP revised up

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world.

The week begins with bullish news from Asia, where Japan's economy grew much faster between April and June than first thought.

A surge in capital expenditure drove GDP up by 3.8% on an annualised basis (or more than +0.9% quarter-on-quarter), the Cabinet Office reported, up from the first estimate of 2.6%.

It's the third successive quarterly rise, and may indicate that prime minister Abe's efforts to reflate the Japanese economy through government spending and a massive stimulus package, are working.

Analysts said the cheery news should pave the way for Abe to hike the Japanese sales tax, an effort to push up revenues and make a (small) dent in Japan's debt mountain.

Hiroako Muto, senior economist at Sumitomo Mitsui Asset Management, explained:

Companies are replacing old equipment, which led to the large upward revision to GDP.

Japan's economic recovery will continue due to strong personal consumption and public works spending. The upward revision means that the government can raise the sales tax as scheduled.

The news came as Tokyo was already celebrating being awarded the 2020 Olympic Games – which offers the promise of further capital expenditure.

Evan Lucas, market strategist at IG Markets in Melbourne, reckoned the bill will be somewhere between the £9bn ($13.9bn) spent on the London 2012 games and the £27bn ($43bn) splashed out on Beijing 2008

For an economy that is desperate to snap out of 20 years of deflation this is a huge shot in the arm.

It's sparked a decent share rally in Asia overnight, where the Nikkei jumped around 2.5%.

More to follow....

Updated at 8.08am BST
